type: ∀ {M : Type u_1} [inst : Monoid M] {s : Set M}, IsSubmonoid s → 1 ∈ s
name: IsSubmonoid.one_mem

A set S is a left transversal of a subgroup H in a group G if and only if the restriction function from S to the quotient G/H is bijective.

type:
∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H : Subgroup G} {S : Set G},
  S ∈ Subgroup.leftTransversals ↑H ↔ Function.Bijective (S.restrict Quotient.mk'')
name: Subgroup.mem_leftTransversals_iff_bijective
docString: A set S is a left transversal of a subgroup H in a group G if and only if the restriction function from S to the quotient G/H is bijective.

This theorem states that for any type `X` equipped with a topological space structure, a set `s` of `X`, and a proposition `p` about elements of `X`, the proposition `p` holds true eventually in the neighborhood filter of the set `s` if and only if there exists a larger open set `t` that contains `s` and the proposition `p` holds true for all elements in `t`. In other words, we can say that a property being true "eventually" in the neighborhood of a set `s` is equivalent to the property being true for all elements of a larger open set that contains `s`. This is a fundamental concept in topology and is used to formalize the notion of continuity and limit.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] {s : Set X} {p : X → Prop},
  (∀ᶠ (x : X) in nhdsSet s, p x) ↔ ∃ t, IsOpen t ∧ s ⊆ t ∧ ∀ x ∈ t, p x
name: eventually_nhdsSet_iff_exists
docString: This theorem states that for any type `X` equipped with a topological space structure, a set `s` of `X`, and a proposition `p` about elements of `X`, the proposition `p` holds true eventually in the neighborhood filter of the set `s` if and only if there exists a larger open set `t` that contains `s` and the proposition `p` holds true for all elements in `t`. In other words, we can say that a property being true "eventually" in the neighborhood of a set `s` is equivalent to the property being true for all elements of a larger open set that contains `s`. This is a fundamental concept in topology and is used to formalize the notion of continuity and limit.

type:
{C : Type u_1} →
  [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{u_3, u_1} C] →
    [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Preadditive C] →
      {S : CategoryTheory.ShortComplex C} → CategoryTheory.ShortComplex.Splitting S → (S.X₂ ⟶ S.X₁)
name: CategoryTheory.ShortComplex.Splitting.r

If `S` is a submonoid of a commutative ring `A` that lies in the complement of the prime ideal generated by the support of a valuation `v` from `A` to a linearly ordered commutative group with zero `Γ`, then every element `s` in `S` is a unit with respect to `v`.

type:
∀ {A : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing A] {Γ : Type u_2} [inst_1 : LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero Γ] (v : Valuation A Γ)
  {S : Submonoid A}, S ≤ v.supp.primeCompl → ∀ (s : ↥S), IsUnit (↑v.toMonoidWithZeroHom ↑s)
name: Valuation.extendToLocalization.proof_2
docString: If `S` is a submonoid of a commutative ring `A` that lies in the complement of the prime ideal generated by the support of a valuation `v` from `A` to a linearly ordered commutative group with zero `Γ`, then every element `s` in `S` is a unit with respect to `v`.

This theorem states the principle of induction over a finite set `S` of an arbitrary type `α`. Specifically, if a property `C` holds for a subset `S0` of `S`, and for any proper subset `s` of `S` on which `C` holds, there exists an element `a` in the difference of `S` and `s` such that `C` also holds on the set resulting from inserting `a` into `s`, then the property `C` must hold for the whole set `S`. This principle is analogous to the induction principle for natural numbers, but applied to finite sets.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} {C : Set α → Prop} {S : Set α},
  S.Finite → ∀ S0 ⊆ S, C S0 → (∀ s ⊂ S, C s → ∃ a ∈ S \ s, C (insert a s)) → C S
name: Set.Finite.induction_to
docString: This theorem states the principle of induction over a finite set `S` of an arbitrary type `α`. Specifically, if a property `C` holds for a subset `S0` of `S`, and for any proper subset `s` of `S` on which `C` holds, there exists an element `a` in the difference of `S` and `s` such that `C` also holds on the set resulting from inserting `a` into `s`, then the property `C` must hold for the whole set `S`. This principle is analogous to the induction principle for natural numbers, but applied to finite sets.

The proposition that s is closed under addition.

type: ∀ {A : Type u_2} [inst : AddMonoid A] {s : Set A}, IsAddSubmonoid s → ∀ {a b : A}, a ∈ s → b ∈ s → a + b ∈ s
name: IsAddSubmonoid.add_mem
docString: The proposition that s is closed under addition.

The sets from `s` cover the whole space.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [t : TopologicalSpace α] {s : Set (Set α)}, TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis s → ⋃₀ s = Set.univ
name: TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis.sUnion_eq
docString: The sets from `s` cover the whole space.

type:

name: AkraBazziRecurrence.b_lt_one

The normal closure of s is a normal subgroup.

A fraction is equal to its expansion by a factor from s.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : Monoid R] {S : Submonoid R} [inst_1 : OreLocalization.OreSet S] (r : R) (s s' : ↥S),
  r /ₒ s = r * ↑s' /ₒ (s * s')
name: OreLocalization.expand'
docString: A fraction is equal to its expansion by a factor from s.
